Title.En: Inventing in a Digital World Using TRIZ and AI

Description.En:
In today’s fast-paced, competitive world, innovation is not just a buzzword; it’s a necessity. But how can you consistently deliver breakthrough ideas and solutions? Enter TRIZ, the Theory of Inventive Problem Solving, a globally recognized methodology that has helped industries tackle their toughest challenges for decades. This micromodule is your chance to dive into this transformative approach and unlock its potential for your academic and professional journey.

What makes this course unique? Unlike traditional innovation methods, TRIZ provides a systematic way to think creatively and solve problems effectively. Enhanced by Artificial Intelligence, this course offers a modern twist to a timeless methodology, giving you a competitive edge in today’s AI-driven industries.

By studying this micromodule, you’ll gain:

- A clear understanding of TRIZ principles and their practical applications.
- Problem-solving skills that will distinguish you in your field.
- The ability to approach challenges with confidence and structure.

This course is designed for learners who want to maximize their innovation capabilities. Whether you’re an engineering student, aspiring entrepreneur, or a curious mind, the skills you gain here are invaluable for standing out in an increasingly demanding job market.

Invest in yourself and your future. Join this micro-module to explore the cutting-edge world of TRIZ and Artificial Intelligence. Equip yourself with tools that turn challenges into opportunities.

Don’t just keep up with innovation—lead it.

You will be able to think outside the box, adapting creatively to changing contexts and complex situations. By the end of this micromodule, you will acquire the tools to generate, structure, and refine novel ideas into actionable and impactful concepts. You will be equipped to systematically apply these ideas to practical challenges, enhancing their relevance and effectiveness. This competency will position you as a key contributor to innovation-driven projects, capable of fostering transformative solutions.

By the end of this micromodule, you will learn to analyze complex problems with a strategic mindset, identifying opportunities to drive innovation and balancing feasibility with visionary thinking. You will develop the ability to approach challenges holistically, integrating diverse perspectives to propose sustainable solutions. This skill will empower you to anticipate and shape future trends in dynamic and competitive environments.

By the end of this micromodule, you will be able to deconstruct complex issues, identify their root causes, and design effective, sustainable solutions. You will also refine your decision-making process by integrating critical and creative thinking. These abilities will enable you to address immediate challenges effectively while planning strategically for long-term success.

MoreInformation.NoteLiteral:
This micro-module is designed to provide a flexible and engaging learning experience, combining synchronous sessions with asynchronous project based activities to maximize accessibility and effectiveness. Below are the details to help you manage your time effectively.

**Synchronous Teaching**

The course includes three live online sessions, each lasting two hours, as well as extensive asynchronous project-based work using the WEB IDEAS platform. These interactive sessions are critical for discussing key TRIZ concepts, participating in live problem-solving exercises, and receiving personalized guidance. The session dates and times are:

- Session 1: Context, History and basics
- Session 2: Problem framing and transforming into a set of contradictory requirements
- Session 3: Solving Contradictions using Altshuller's Matrix & 40 inventive Principles

**Asynchronous Work:**

Students will dedicate significant time to a hands-on project utilizing the WEB IDEAS platform to conceptualize, design, and propose an innovative object or system. This project is supported by asynchronous resources, collaboration tools, and periodic feedback. Project-Based Learning Integration Project Focus:

Students will explore real-world problems and apply TRIZ methodologies using the WEB IDEAS platform.

The platform facilitates collaborative brainstorming, inventive problem-solving, and the creation of detailed proposals for innovative designs.

**Final Deliverable: Each team will present a comprehensive proposal, supported by concept sketches or prototypes, demonstrating the practical application of TRIZ principles.**

**Assessment Strategy**

Your progress will be evaluated through a combination of practical and theoretical assessments:

- Individual Project (60%): Students will apply TRIZ principles to develop and present an innovative object or system, with detailed documentation of their approach and solutions.
- Online Quiz (20%): A multiple-choice quiz covering theoretical aspects of TRIZ, conducted after the final synchronous session.
- Participation (20%): Active involvement during live sessions and meaningful contributions in asynchronous discussions and project activities.

**Time Commitment**

The module requires approximately 40 hours of work, structured as follows:

- Synchronous Learning: 6 hours (3 sessions x 2 hours).
- Asynchronous Learning: 34 hours, including: Independent study and review of TRIZ resources. Team-based project development using the WEB IDEAS platform. Participation in discussion forums and collaborative activities.

Applying for this engaging micromodule on the Theory of Inventive Problem Solving (TRIZ) is straightforward and designed to ensure that participants are well-prepared to make the most of the experience. This micromodule is ideal for students currently pursuing engineering, business, or related disciplines at the undergraduate or graduate level. A basic understanding of problem-solving methods or innovation frameworks is helpful but not mandatory, as the course provides foundational knowledge to support all learners.

To apply, students should submit the following documents:

- A CV highlighting academic and professional achievements relevant to the field of innovation or problem-solving.
- A transcript of recent academic records to showcase your educational background.
- A short covering letter (200–300 words) explaining your motivation for joining this micromodule and how you plan to apply the concepts learned.
